Subject: NEAT and highly recurrent networks
X-Yahoo-Group-Post: member; u=279942280; y=R_5cwCk6eEUv3y41EiPT-j0rV-JLTFQS_QRa-_PePuyMRoC0

I've been working on my own implimentation of NEAT (having to fit to a
pred=
escribed framework) and while it's mostly working, I'm looking at
a couple =
of questions.

First, I know that the networks that NEAT generates can have=

recurrency (feedback), and this is likely why some of the robot game
examp=
les work well.  However, I'm looking at trying to use NEAT to
find patterns=
 in time series data, as one would use fully recurrent
networks for (In the=
se, also known as Elmen networks, all of the
hidden layer and output layer =
values are 'propagated' into the next
time step to give the network memory,=
 with full connectivity between
all the input and previous nodes to the hid=
den/output nodes).

Such a network should be possible to be generated by NE=
AT, though I
figure that not every recurrent type problem needs a fully rec=
urrent
network.  So I'm trying to use NEAT to generate such, using the
clas=
sic delayed-XOR problem (such that the result of xor of the two
current inp=
uts will be the actual output some time steps away).  Fully
recurrent netwo=
rks can be trained to do this, but I want to generate a
NEAT network that, =
after running through the fixed data series a
number of relaxation times, t=
hat the weights have already been trained
through NEAT evolution such that =
I don't have to perform additional
training on the network.  

Has anyone h=
ad any success directly in generating such recurrent
networks?  I know my f=
itnesses improve with time, but it takes a lot
of generations (1000+ with a=
 150 member population) to even see
something, and even then, it's not anyw=
here close to what simple
recurrent training can provide.  (This may be als=
o related to my
second question).

The other question I had was about conve=
rgence times.  I'm trying to
test my network on the normal XOR problem (non=
-recurrent mode) and
find that it takes many more evolution generations for=
 the fitness to
get to acceptable levels (based solely on the distance of e=
xpected vs
observed output), exceptionaly more than listed in the NEAT pape=
rs
(500-1000 evolution steps as opposed to 10-30 steps) even when using
wha=
t I believe are the same values described by Kenneth in his papers.
 I've t=
ried nearly every parameter, and the only one that I know I
want to keep lo=
w is the new node probability to avoid excessive growth
of the network.  An=
yone have any pointers on what parameters are
critical to help with rapid c=
onvergence on the best network?  Mind
you, it could still be something in m=
y code which I've been pounding
through to try to find differences.

Anothe=
r related question is on the species comparison expression and
tolerance.  =
I tend to use N=3Dnumber of genes in largest species
regardless of the case=
, and for that I have to play with the tolerance
as to get 5 or more specie=
s in a population of 150.  Is there an ideal
average number of species that=
 you want to carry through in the
population in order to take advantage of =
NEAT's use of species?  And
when do people move away from the 'typical' val=
ues of the coefficients
(1 and 1 for disjoint and excess elements, 0.4 for =
weight difference
average)
